The best advice I can give you is to make your itinerary fit your time frame. Don’t try to make the time fit your ideal itinerary. Because most things can be done, at least logistically. So you’d be able to get to all these places in the time indicated but you certainly won’t have enough time to explore them or to get to know them in any meaningful way. You’ll spend too great a portion of your time transiting from location to location to actually absorb the charm of any place.

Everyone’s different of course but I don’t go abroad to spend my time on trains, on planes, or in a car. I go to experience a different culture, to learn new things, to be enriched, and to enjoy myself. Those things happen from “boots on the ground exploration,”
not from rushed transiting around.

Keep in mind that there’s a huge difference between “seeing” something and experiencing it. An itinerary that crams too many places into too few days doesn’t allow for much experiencing. You might have the time to rush from one tourist spot to the next so you can wrap things up in that location just to move on to the next location that you’ll also have to rush through to move onto your next stop. In my book that’s just not pleasant. To let these places work their magic on you you should slow it down a bit. Allow yourself the time to do these types of things; 1. to stroll various neighborhoods at will with no goal in mind, just absorbing the unique charm. 2. To watch a sunset. 3. To enjoy a drink while people watching on a busy piazza. 4. To strike up conversations with locals. 5. To sample every gelato shop you stumble on. 6. To pop into any little mom and pop store that interests you. 7. To wander narrow twisty streets at night until you’re hopelessly lost, then to somehow miraculously find your way back. 8. To detour from your itinerary when something unexpected interests you. And 9. To kick a soccer ball around with a group of kids. These are the things that you sacrifice by moving too quickly. They might seem like small things but when you look back on your travels you find they’re somehow the most important things. These are the things that are fun. That you’ll enjoy doing. Rushing around to see the so called highlights isn’t very much fun & is actually stressful and causes exhaustion.

For what they’re worth these are my thoughts

Since you’re landing in & leaving from Venice it only makes sense to spend some time in this magical, mystical place. You’re landing there so you can visit it without incurring any additional transportation costs or wasting additional hours transiting to it. You’ll be landing in a unique place that’s one of the most visually stunning cities in the world. So spend a couple days having fun there!!

Florence and Rome also each deserve more time. (And most importantly, you yourself deserve more time in each amazing place.) So I’d eliminate the Amslfi Coast. Not because I don’t like it, because I do, but because it’s geographically the outlier here. It’s not near your other target locations so going there will make it take longer to get back to Venice for your return flight. Eliminating your farthest flung destination will mean fewer hours spent in transit and more hours available for exploration elsewhere. Plus you’d have two days to pay with. I’d add one of those days to Venice and 1 to Florence. I honestly think you’d enjoy yourself much more that way.

One thing to remember is to account for travel time when planning. Each time you change cities you’re going to lose one half to one full day of sightseeing time. You have to add the actual number of scheduled travel hours (say two by train just as an example) to the time it takes to check out of one hotel and travel to the station. Then add the time it takes to travel through the streets of an unfamiliar city to get to your next hotel and check in. In even the best case scenario thst two hour train ride actually takes up a good 4 hours of the day. And quite often you won’t have the best case scenario. Because trains, planes, etc can be delayed or run late, you might encounter a train strike. You might hit a traffic congestion getting to your new hotel. So depending on how things go the 2 days you’re allotting to Florence, for example, will actually only be 1 and a half days of sightseeing. And you lose that much time (or probably more) each and every time you change cities.

I don’t want to be negative but I thing it’s important you understand the realities of so much transiting around.

No one can do everything on any one trip. The key to a successful trip is to do as much as you can realistically do while still having fun in each place. I think your itinerary doesn’t allow for much fun so it should be tweaked to allow time for that.

But again everyone’s different. You have to design an itinerary that suits you.

text:
Hi everyone!
We just got back to Canada after our 10 year wedding anniversary in Italy. This was my husband’s first time and my second trip to Italy. Here’s how our trip went and places we’ve stayed and love.

Flew direct Yul-Fco with AC no problem at all even got in early. Stayed in Rome 2 nights at the Damaso Hotel; super central hotel, right by Campo do Fiore, beautiful, amazing staff, highly recommended it. We Armando del Pantheon, this is probably the only place our hole trip that I do not recommend; pasta was extremely salty and overall food not good; it’s clearly become a tourist trap. Had dinner at Pianostrada Laboratorio Di Cucina; beautiful terrace garden and food was great. We did the Vatican 730am breakfast tour; a must, we were all by ourselves with our group in each hall way, yes to see the Basilica we had to go back through the museum with all the people but we simply walked at a fast pasted and got to the side chapel door in about 10 minutes and were able to cut the huge line waiting to get in. Had lunch that day in the basement cellar of Roscioli; amazing, we loved everything we ate and the setting is pretty cool. We then had the night tour of the Colosseum underground that we booked with Get Your Guide ; we were lucky enough ours wasn’t cancel, but I could suggest booking directly with the actual tour company called « Italy With Family », I think your chance of cancellation will be less. We had also book an Italian tour directly with the colosseum just in case but we’re lucky we didn’t need it.

Then took a morning train with Italo from Rome to Florence. I highly suggest booking with Italo. Someone on here had complained about the AC on the trainitalia, well this wasn’t an issue on Italo, the train was basically empty in primo class, train seemed new and ac worked great.

Arrived at the Florence terminal we jumped in a cab and headed to Tuscany. I had done a tone of research trying to find the perfect place to stay and let me tell you, I did!! We had a 2 night romance package at this incredible estate called « Torre a Cona » (or Fattoria Torre a Cona). The vineyard itself has existed for hundreds of years but the estate was transformed into this incredible small hotel and restaurant with a Michelin star chef. The property is simply wonderful with a beautiful pool. I would highly suggest staying here soon before they become highly popular, as I’m sure their prices will go up.

We didn’t want to drive and prices for a driver were to us outrageous, so we took taxis everywhere and it worked out great. We did a wine tour with dinner pairing at our estate, a wine tour of Antinori nel Classico Chianti (highly recommend) and we had dinner at Ruffino winery (dinner was alright, over priced and not our best meal but the gardens with table and music are magical; would suggest going for a drink and appetizers in their gardens only).

We then had a taxi come pick us up at 6am to take us to Florence where we were to catch a bus tour to Cinque Terre. Even though the tour company said we could bring our luggage on the bus, we opted to drop them off at our hotel first; oh how happy we did. The meeting point is at the train terminal but because buses aren’t allowed at the terminal, they make you walk 10-15 minutes away.

The tour of Cinque Terre itself is about 12-14 hours there and back. The guides were amazing. They give you the train ticket at the beginning, take you from one town to an other with some info of each town and some free time. Unfortunately the day we were there the sea was extremely rough and our boat part of the tour was cancelled; meaning we lost a bit of that feel/charm of what Cinque Terre really is, but on the last town you really get to experience seeing all the colored homes. The tour was great, but because I had been to the Amalfi coast in the past I would now choose to go back to the amalfi coast over cinque Terre as I find it is simply not as well maintained.

Back to Florence at 9pm, this is where we wished we had had at least a full day in Florence. The people are all so nice the city very charming. But from 9-midnight we made the best of it by eating at this restaurant right next to our hotel called Yellow Bar; OMG best best pasta of our hole trip. My husband even said at the end of our trip that he wished he could just go back there and have one more meal. We stayed at Hotel Cavour; beautiful hotel right by the duomo. We had made a rooftop reservation for 10pm so we could at least have a view of the city; incredible!

Short night sleep, 4 am taxi to the airport to catch our flight to Sardinia. 3 nights at the Hotel Villa Margherita in Golfo Aranci. We again didn’t drive and took a taxi to other beaches, but here during the day you could probably safely drive and see tons of incredible beaches. There’s a well known pizza restaurant called Pizzaria La PechoraViziosa; amazing pizza and even better ambiance (highly suggest making a reservation for upstairs). Sardinia is a beautiful island with thousands of options to stay. Next time we would love to try south, but anywhere the water and sand is simply breathtaking.

Finally, back to the airport by taxi; flew Sardinia-Rome then Rome-Montreal.

We were the lucky ones, zero delays and everything went without a hitch. We never saw one pick pocket (and I’m a traveler and very aware). Never had to use a toilet without a toilet seat. Was hot only the 2 days in Rome as we were there at the end of the heat wave but then the temperature went back down to normal summer temp. We never found it over crowded; the ones that think haven’t travelled much as there’s way worst out there.

Do what’s right for you. If your nervous about things like getting somewhere then give yourself some extra time. I go to Europe every couple of years and the people, the food, the landscapes are all always magical and good for the soul. Don’t let anything ruin that moment, take it all in.
